abstracts.cdata!:
This report is a project performance
            review of the Third Power Project in Panama. The physical
            objectives of the project were substantially achieved. A new
            25 MW diesel plant was added to the system; transmission
            lines, substations and a modern load dispatch center were
            constructed; and distribution systems were expanded.
            However, the project was completed 28 months behind schedule
            with a cost overrun of 25 percent. The delay in the
            installation of the power plant resulted in power shortages
            in the period 1975-76. Although the rate of return for the
            power plant is negative, Instituto de Recursos Hidraulicos y
            Electrificacion (IRHE) overall investment program continued
            having a high rate of return comparable to appraisal
            estimates. Although energy sales grew much slower than
            expected, the timing of the project was not premature, as
            the new power plant has been used to meet peak demand in
            normal hydrological years and to replace hydro-energy during
            dry periods.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Third IBRD Power Project will help
            to interconnect the regional systems and also help meet the
            regular increase of Panama's power needs. The Project
            would consist of: (a) a thermal power plant of about 25 MW
            to be installed in the metropolitan area; (b) about 188 km
            of 230 kV double-circuit transmission lines between Panama
            Substation, Chorrera and Divisa; (c) about 41km of 115 kV
            single-circuit transmission lines between Chitre and Divisa,
            and about 25 km of 115 kV double-circuit transmission lines
            in the metropolitan area; (d) substations with a total
            capacity of about 200 MVA for transforming from 115 kV and
            for switching; (e) about 110 km of subtransmission lines and
            related substations; (f) expansion of distribution systems
            in both urban and rural areas; (g) a system load dispatch
            center at the Panama substation, including a related
            communication system; and (h) studies, engineering and
            technical training.
